overview_of_class: To succeed in health science related courses students need a mental framework of human biology to which they can add vast amounts of information; without one, students will often "lose the forest in the trees" and end up overwhelmed by information-dumps challenging even for the best of us. Concepts of Biology is designed to show students the big picture. By the end of the course, students will have developed a mental framework of human biology which they will use in all subsequent health science related courses to not only manage copious amounts of new information, but deeply and efficiently learn them as well. We will construct this framework by breaking down a human being into its component parts, focusing on one part at a time. We will also factor in natural selection ("evolution"), how it works, and at what organizational levels of a human being it acts on. The course is represented schematically in Figure 1; throughout the course we will continually refer back to this schematic to ensure concepts are learned within the context of the whole.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None. This is an intro to bio course. If all you've had is bio from high school that is completely fine. If you've had more advanced courses, that is ok too. I have designed this course to be engaging for students of all levels.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Break down a human being into its component parts - atoms & molecules, cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems - and describe how each of the parts contribute to building the whole.
2) Describe what natural selection is and how it acts on the different levels of organization, from human beings as a whole down to the level of atoms and molecules.

In addition to these, each unit will include its own specific learning objectives. These will be measured through online discussion boards and quizzes (some quizzes graded for participation, others graded for accuracy). There will also be a 1 - 2 page writing assignment at the end of the course to tie it all together.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Class participation
Online lecture + interactive quizzes (graded for participation only)
Online discussion board posts (Yellowdig)
Readings
Independent research (minimal)
Videos

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Participation (in-lecture quizzes, discussion board posts)
Quizzes after each unit (around 10 points each)
Writing assignment at the end

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Students are required to purchase the textbook: Biology: Life on Earth, tenth edition. 2014. Teresa Audesirk, Gerald Audesirk, & Bruce E. Byers. Published by Benjamin Cummings (an imprint of Pearson). Print text (ISBN-13: 978-0-321-79426-0). Text is available from campus bookstore, www.coursemart.com, or other booksellers.

Other materials may include freely available online resources and texts posted to Canvas.
